child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. The classification of South American languages. In Lyle Campbell & Verónica Grondona (eds.), South America. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. , Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 69. London, New York: Routledge.

child.alt-names: Shuar; Achuar-Shiwiar, Achual, Hivaro, Maina, Huambisa, Jíbaro
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. The classification of South American languages. In Lyle Campbell & Verónica Grondona (eds.), South America. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. , Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 69. London, New York: Routledge.

root.pub-comments: These could be dialects or languages. Kaufman (2007:69) considers Jívaro a “language area” with two emergent languages, Jívaro [Hivaro] and Aguaruna [Awaruna] (Awahun). Adelaar (2004:616) and Ethnologue list four Jivaroan languages: Aguaruna, Achuar (Achual), Huambisa, and Shuar. Palta (Eucador) is sometimes said to be related to Jivaroan (Loukotka 1968:157), though Kuafman (2007:69) says it “shows little resemblance.” Adelaar also lists Xoroca (also called Palta) as Jivaroan, a hypothesis Torero (2002:284-7) also appeared to favored. Malacato (Ecuador), another extinct language, is often associated with Jivaroan (Loukotka 1968:157). Loukotka (1968:157) considered Huambisa and “Achual,” together with Antipa, Gualaquiza, Upano, Canelo (Penday), and Bolona, to be dialects of “Jíbaro” (Shuara). Torero (2002:287) believed in a “Palta-Jíbaro” family, but where two branches needed to be distinguished, “Palta-Malacata” (perhaps also with Cumbinamá] and the Jíbaro branch.
root.publications: Campbell, Lyle. The classification of South American languages. In Lyle Campbell & Verónica Grondona (eds.), South America. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. , Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 69. London, New York: Routledge.
